transcript:
Patient: Sure, I can share an example from my thought records. Last week, I was at the language learners meetup, and during a break, I found myself standing alone while everyone else seemed to be chatting easily in groups. I started feeling really overwhelmed and anxious, like I didn't belong there and wasn't interesting enough for anyone to want to talk to me.

Therapist: That sounds like a challenging situation, Jamie. I appreciate you sharing it. Let's walk through the thought record together. What automatic thoughts did you notice in that moment?

Patient: I had thoughts like "I'm not interesting or likable enough for people to want to connect with me" and "I don't belong here, everyone else is more outgoing and confident than me."

Therapist: Those are important automatic thoughts to identify. What evidence did you find for and against those thoughts?

Patient: Well, as evidence for the thoughts, I noticed that I was standing alone and that people weren't approaching me to chat. But as evidence against the thoughts, I reminded myself that I had some good conversations earlier in the evening, and that people seemed interested in my language learning experiences. I also tried to remember that just because I'm not chatting easily with everyone, it doesn't mean I don't belong there or that people don't like me.

Therapist: That's a great example of examining the evidence for and against your automatic thoughts, Jamie. It's powerful to recognize that there is evidence on both sides, and that the initial thoughts may not be completely accurate. Were you able to generate any alternative thoughts in that moment?

Patient: It was tough, but I tried to tell myself something like "I may not connect easily with everyone, but I have unique interests and experiences that some people appreciate" and "It's okay to take my time and not pressure myself to be super outgoing."

Therapist: Those are really adaptive alternative thoughts, Jamie. Even if it was difficult to fully believe them in the moment, just practicing generating those thoughts is a big step forward. It's about building new mental habits over time.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. It's helpful to walk through it like this. I can see how the thought record helps me challenge those automatic thoughts and see things from a different perspective.

Therapist: Absolutely, Jamie. And even if you don't always feel better instantly, consistently practicing the thought records helps build resilience and flexibility in your thinking over time. It's a skill that you're developing.

Patient: I can see that. It's just hard to remember to do it in the moment when I'm feeling overwhelmed.

Therapist: That's a great point, Jamie. That's where the coping card can come in handy. Did you have a chance to use your coping card in that situation at the meetup?

Patient: I did try to use it. I took a moment to step aside and read through the coping statements I had written down, like "I am learning and growing" and "I can take my time and be myself." It helped a little bit to ground me and remind me of the bigger picture.

Therapist: That's wonderful that you were able to use the coping card in that moment, Jamie. Even if it didn't take away all the anxiety, it's a success that you were able to access those coping thoughts and give yourself a different perspective. That's a skill you can build on.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. I'm starting to see how these techniques can help over time, even if it's not a quick fix.

Therapist: You're absolutely right, Jamie. It's not about perfection or instant results. It's about consistently practicing these skills and building new mental habits over time. And you're doing a great job of that.

Patient: Thanks for the encouragement. I'm trying to be patient with myself and trust the process.

Therapist: That's a great attitude to have, Jamie. And speaking of the process, I'm curious about your experience with practicing vulnerability at the meetup. You mentioned that you pushed yourself to share a bit more about your background and interests. How did that feel for you?

Patient: It was definitely scary to put myself out there more. I felt really nervous and exposed at first. But as I started sharing a bit about my language learning journey and some of my cultural experiences, I noticed that people seemed interested and engaged. It felt good to connect on a deeper level, even if it was uncomfortable at first.

Therapist: That's a really brave thing you did, Jamie. It takes a lot of courage to be vulnerable and share more of yourself with others. And it's great that you noticed the positive response from people. That's evidence against those negative core beliefs about not being interesting or likable enough.

Patient: You're right. It's just hard to break out of that mindset sometimes.

Therapist: Absolutely, Jamie. Those core beliefs can be really entrenched and it takes time and practice to shift them. But every time you challenge yourself to be vulnerable and have a positive experience, it chips away at those negative beliefs a little bit. It's a process of gradually building new evidence and new beliefs about yourself.

Patient: That makes sense. I guess I need to keep putting myself out there, even if it's uncomfortable.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Jamie. And remember, it's not about doing it perfectly or being vulnerable all the time. It's about taking small risks and building up those experiences over time. And being compassionate with yourself in the process.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. I'm starting to see how all these pieces fit together - the thought records, the coping card, the vulnerability practice. It's a lot to work on, but I'm feeling more hopeful about it.

Therapist: You're doing an amazing job, Jamie. It's a lot to work on, but you're making really important progress. And we'll keep working on it together. Remember, it's not about being perfect, it's about consistently practicing these skills and being kind to yourself in the process.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. That means a lot to hear you say that. I'm looking forward to continuing our work together.
